title: Is 'seem to have been' the same thing as 'have seemed to have been'? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, the timelines are different. And the second construction can really only appear with a modal auxiliary verb (where have is a bare infinitive). They seem to have been ill. ✓ They seemed to have been ill. ✓ They might seem to have been ill. ✓ They might have seemed to have been ill. ✓ They have seemed to have been ill. ✗ (incorrect)

It’s hard to construct a sentence using “have seemed to have been,” and without such a sentence to test I can’t give a definite answer. In just about every instance—every instance I can imagine right now, anyway—”seem to have been” seems more apt and natural than the longer and cumbersome “have seemed to have been.” If you can provide a longer text, it might be possible to give you a better answer.

No. In both cases the “being” happened at some time in the past, and “have been” is used to deemphasize the exact time and imply that it was unimportant. But with “seem to have been”, the “seeming” is happening in the present but with “have seemed to have been” the seeming happened at an unimportant time in the past.

Is "seem to have been" the same thing as "have seemed to have been"? No. There is no reason to use the present perfect tense twice for the same reason. The first one is correct. But you could use the past tense, as in the following: “They seemed to have been.”

“[They] seem to have been…” signifies the present appearance of the effects of something on a group of people. “[They] have seemed to have been…” signifies a their appearance in the past. As examples: “They seem to have been in the sunshine” (i.e. they currently look hot). ”They have seemed to have been in the sunshine.” (At some point in the past they have looked hot).
